item.title: Crack models of small repeating earthquakes
item.description: with Paul Segall Comparison between numerical simulations (dots) and analytical results (blue line), showing the $T_r\sim M_0^{1/ 6}$ scaling observed in nature. The blue line and red lines indicate the recurrence time derived analytically (and they apply for $R\lesssim 4.2R_{\infty}$ and $R\gtrsim 4.2R_{\infty} respectively$). Small repeating earthquakes are events characterized by very similar waveforms, and overlapping rupture areas. Unlike most other earthquakes, they are very periodic; they are commonly interpreted as rupturing an isolated asperity embedded in a velocity-strengthening (creeping) fault.

item.title: Dynamic Triggering at Oceanic Transform Faults
Earthquake Cycle and time-dependent coupling in Subduction Zones
item.description: with Paul Segall and Kaj Johnson The Mw 9.0 2011 Tohoku earthquake was preceded by a acceleration of the plate interface, as indicated by nonlinear trends in the GPS time series (1996-2011) as well as repeating events (for more detail, see here). Moreover, an increase in the frequency of M7+ earthquakes was observed during this period, including a Mw 7.3 foreshock two days before the Tohoku earthquake. These observations indicate that plate coupling and seismicity rates are not constant throughout the seismic cycle; the traditional distinction into “stick-slip” asperities (locked interseismically, and slipping during earthquakes) and creeping regions (slipping interseismically, and not coseismically) needs to be revised, as confirmed by multiple studies in Japan and elsewhere.

item.title: Seismic swarms and aseismic slip driven by dikes
Static stress triggering in Operational Earthquake Forecasting
item.description: During my PhD, I developed physical models of aftershock sequences based on Coulomb stress transfer, in the context of probabilistic earthquake forecasting: the goal was to improve the statistical performance of aftershock models. My approach has been guided by an attempt to construct physically consistent and realistic models of the processes involved. I have addressed two questions: (1) what is the effect of afterslip on seismicity? (2) how can we realistically model the heterogeneity of the stress field produced by large earthquakes?
